Ticket.description: I have a couple users in a 300+ user environment that are having issues printing from word or outlook or even notepad. When they go to print, upon hitting print the program freezes. When you open the devices and printer window, it takes for ever to load and then it hangs at the end. I've found that when trying to restart the print spooler it comes up with an error 1053: the service did not respond. I've tried enabling the Bluetooth support service and set it to run automatically but that doesn't work. I also found out that you have to try and load the printers and devices, open up the services and attempt to restart the print spooler, wait for it to timeout, refresh the printer and devices window, start the print spooler and then do it all again one more time for it to fix the issue. I'm looking for a permanent fix to this issue. I've tried imagining the computer even reinstalling it from scratch but the error keeps coming back.

Ticket.description:
Alrighty everyone, here's the situation.

We've got a couple of Windows 10 pro computers, running a second copy of Windows 10 pro within a Hyper-V virtual machine that's connected to a different domain.  Both the host machine, and the VM have Office 2016 installed via an Office 365 subscription.

On the host machine, when we right-click on an .xlsx file and select 'print', the Excel file prints successfully to the default printer and if you look in the process list, the Excel.exe process that opens during the print, closes successfully.

However, on the VM, if you attempt the same thing, the excel.exe process does not get closed.
In fact, Excel will leave an Excel.exe process open for each file that you right-click > print.

I tested this on 2 different workstations set up this way, and both behaved the same way.  Both Windows and MS Office have been fully updated.

This is an issue as one of our users prints a lot of excel docs and eventually runs out of memory on the VM due to all of the leftover Excel.exe processes.

I did find that if you open Excel first and just minimize it, and then right-click > print the .xlsx files you need to print, the Excel.exe processes close properly when they are done being printed.

The workaround works for now, however it would be great if anyone knows of a way to fix this permanently.

Ticket.description:
We are having issues adding a second Connection Broker to our system.

Server configurations:

1 - RDS-Connection Broker - Windows 2012 R2


3 - RDS- Session Hosts - Windows 2012 R2


1 - Machine we want to add RDS-CB to (RDS-MGR) and is running the SQL Express 2016 for the HA and the OS is Windows 2012 R2.

This all started because we were wanting to move the RDS-CB off of the server it is currently on.  (Current server is the DC).  So through some investigating we found that the best way to do this is to set up the HA, add the new server, then remove the existing server.  We have followed the information at this link: https://thewolfblog.com/2014/02/02/configuring-ha-for-the-remote-desktop-connection-broker/ to a "T" (as well as a few others that were pretty well the same with slight differences).  We have been successful in getting the HA configured and the database moved to the SQL Express 2016.  We are having issues getting the new server added as a broker now.  We are getting an error:


"The database specified in the connection string Driver=SQL Server Native Client 11.0;SERVER=RDS-MGR\RDSQL;Trusted_Connection=Yes;APP=Remote Desktop Services Connection Broker;DATABASE=RDSQL is not available from the RD Connection Broker server RDS-MGR.domain.  Ensure that the database server is available on the network, the SQL Server Native Client is installed on all RD Connection Broker servers, and the computer accounts of the RD Connection Broker servers are members of the RDS Management Servers group on the database server."


We have created a new separate test server to see if it can be configured as an RDS CB server, and it gets the same error when trying to add it. 


The original CB server and the two new servers all have the SQL client on them and all pass the connection test when going through the ODBC configuration.  Firewall has been turned off on all involved servers to ensure that it is not interfering.  The test server and new server have been rebooted several times (cannot reboot the original server right now).  We have checked that the servers are added to the AD security group that is used in the SQL authentication.

We cannot figure out why this is not connecting.


Any assistance will be greatly appreciated.

Usually, this works fine.

Frequently enough, though (usually get at least a couple reports per day), after logging in to the server, the userinit.exe program will get an "Access is denied" error trying to launch the initial program.  The login itself is successful as I can open Task Manager and use it to launch Windows Explorer; I can even manually launch the program itself without problems at that point.

This uses an unprivileged service account, the same one for every application and every person, and passes the password information into the call to the initial program (this has the unfortunate side effect of revealing their current password in the error box that comes up, though it resets every 24 hours).  I do see security log audit failures for the service account around the times it acts up.  The entries look like this:

We cannot figure out why this is not connecting.

Ticket.description:
Alrighty everyone, here's the situation.

We've got a couple of Windows 10 pro computers, running a second copy of Windows 10 pro within a Hyper-V virtual machine that's connected to a different domain.  Both the host machine, and the VM have Office 2016 installed via an Office 365 subscription.

On the host machine, when we right-click on an .xlsx file and select 'print', the Excel file prints successfully to the default printer and if you look in the process list, the Excel.exe process that opens during the print, closes successfully.

However, on the VM, if you attempt the same thing, the excel.exe process does not get closed.
In fact, Excel will leave an Excel.exe process open for each file that you right-click > print.

I tested this on 2 different workstations set up this way, and both behaved the same way.  Both Windows and MS Office have been fully updated.

This is an issue as one of our users prints a lot of excel docs and eventually runs out of memory on the VM due to all of the leftover Excel.exe processes.

I did find that if you open Excel first and just minimize it, and then right-click > print the .xlsx files you need to print, the Excel.exe processes close properly when they are done being printed.

The workaround works for now, however it would be great if anyone knows of a way to fix this permanently.

Ticket.description:
We are having issues adding a second Connection Broker to our system.

Server configurations:

1 - RDS-Connection Broker - Windows 2012 R2


3 - RDS- Session Hosts - Windows 2012 R2


1 - Machine we want to add RDS-CB to (RDS-MGR) and is running the SQL Express 2016 for the HA and the OS is Windows 2012 R2.

This all started because we were wanting to move the RDS-CB off of the server it is currently on.  (Current server is the DC).  So through some investigating we found that the best way to do this is to set up the HA, add the new server, then remove the existing server.  We have followed the information at this link: https://thewolfblog.com/2014/02/02/configuring-ha-for-the-remote-desktop-connection-broker/ to a "T" (as well as a few others that were pretty well the same with slight differences).  We have been successful in getting the HA configured and the database moved to the SQL Express 2016.  We are having issues getting the new server added as a broker now.  We are getting an error:


"The database specified in the connection string Driver=SQL Server Native Client 11.0;SERVER=RDS-MGR\RDSQL;Trusted_Connection=Yes;APP=Remote Desktop Services Connection Broker;DATABASE=RDSQL is not available from the RD Connection Broker server RDS-MGR.domain.  Ensure that the database server is available on the network, the SQL Server Native Client is installed on all RD Connection Broker servers, and the computer accounts of the RD Connection Broker servers are members of the RDS Management Servers group on the database server."


We have created a new separate test server to see if it can be configured as an RDS CB server, and it gets the same error when trying to add it. 


The original CB server and the two new servers all have the SQL client on them and all pass the connection test when going through the ODBC configuration.  Firewall has been turned off on all involved servers to ensure that it is not interfering.  The test server and new server have been rebooted several times (cannot reboot the original server right now).  We have checked that the servers are added to the AD security group that is used in the SQL authentication.

We cannot figure out why this is not connecting.


Any assistance will be greatly appreciated.

Ticket.description: I have a couple users in a 300+ user environment that are having issues printing from word or outlook or even notepad. When they go to print, upon hitting print the program freezes. When you open the devices and printer window, it takes for ever to load and then it hangs at the end. I've found that when trying to restart the print spooler it comes up with an error 1053: the service did not respond. I've tried enabling the Bluetooth support service and set it to run automatically but that doesn't work. I also found out that you have to try and load the printers and devices, open up the services and attempt to restart the print spooler, wait for it to timeout, refresh the printer and devices window, start the print spooler and then do it all again one more time for it to fix the issue. I'm looking for a permanent fix to this issue. I've tried imagining the computer even reinstalling it from scratch but the error keeps coming back.

Ticket.description:
Alrighty everyone, here's the situation.

We've got a couple of Windows 10 pro computers, running a second copy of Windows 10 pro within a Hyper-V virtual machine that's connected to a different domain.  Both the host machine, and the VM have Office 2016 installed via an Office 365 subscription.

On the host machine, when we right-click on an .xlsx file and select 'print', the Excel file prints successfully to the default printer and if you look in the process list, the Excel.exe process that opens during the print, closes successfully.

However, on the VM, if you attempt the same thing, the excel.exe process does not get closed.
In fact, Excel will leave an Excel.exe process open for each file that you right-click > print.

I tested this on 2 different workstations set up this way, and both behaved the same way.  Both Windows and MS Office have been fully updated.

This is an issue as one of our users prints a lot of excel docs and eventually runs out of memory on the VM due to all of the leftover Excel.exe processes.

I did find that if you open Excel first and just minimize it, and then right-click > print the .xlsx files you need to print, the Excel.exe processes close properly when they are done being printed.

The workaround works for now, however it would be great if anyone knows of a way to fix this permanently.

Ticket.description:
We are having issues adding a second Connection Broker to our system.

Server configurations:

1 - RDS-Connection Broker - Windows 2012 R2


3 - RDS- Session Hosts - Windows 2012 R2


1 - Machine we want to add RDS-CB to (RDS-MGR) and is running the SQL Express 2016 for the HA and the OS is Windows 2012 R2.

This all started because we were wanting to move the RDS-CB off of the server it is currently on.  (Current server is the DC).  So through some investigating we found that the best way to do this is to set up the HA, add the new server, then remove the existing server.  We have followed the information at this link: https://thewolfblog.com/2014/02/02/configuring-ha-for-the-remote-desktop-connection-broker/ to a "T" (as well as a few others that were pretty well the same with slight differences).  We have been successful in getting the HA configured and the database moved to the SQL Express 2016.  We are having issues getting the new server added as a broker now.  We are getting an error:


"The database specified in the connection string Driver=SQL Server Native Client 11.0;SERVER=RDS-MGR\RDSQL;Trusted_Connection=Yes;APP=Remote Desktop Services Connection Broker;DATABASE=RDSQL is not available from the RD Connection Broker server RDS-MGR.domain.  Ensure that the database server is available on the network, the SQL Server Native Client is installed on all RD Connection Broker servers, and the computer accounts of the RD Connection Broker servers are members of the RDS Management Servers group on the database server."


We have created a new separate test server to see if it can be configured as an RDS CB server, and it gets the same error when trying to add it. 


The original CB server and the two new servers all have the SQL client on them and all pass the connection test when going through the ODBC configuration.  Firewall has been turned off on all involved servers to ensure that it is not interfering.  The test server and new server have been rebooted several times (cannot reboot the original server right now).  We have checked that the servers are added to the AD security group that is used in the SQL authentication.

We cannot figure out why this is not connecting.


Any assistance will be greatly appreciated.

Ticket.description: I have a couple users in a 300+ user environment that are having issues printing from word or outlook or even notepad. When they go to print, upon hitting print the program freezes. When you open the devices and printer window, it takes for ever to load and then it hangs at the end. I've found that when trying to restart the print spooler it comes up with an error 1053: the service did not respond. I've tried enabling the Bluetooth support service and set it to run automatically but that doesn't work. I also found out that you have to try and load the printers and devices, open up the services and attempt to restart the print spooler, wait for it to timeout, refresh the printer and devices window, start the print spooler and then do it all again one more time for it to fix the issue. I'm looking for a permanent fix to this issue. I've tried imagining the computer even reinstalling it from scratch but the error keeps coming back.

Ticket.description:
Alrighty everyone, here's the situation.

We've got a couple of Windows 10 pro computers, running a second copy of Windows 10 pro within a Hyper-V virtual machine that's connected to a different domain.  Both the host machine, and the VM have Office 2016 installed via an Office 365 subscription.

On the host machine, when we right-click on an .xlsx file and select 'print', the Excel file prints successfully to the default printer and if you look in the process list, the Excel.exe process that opens during the print, closes successfully.

However, on the VM, if you attempt the same thing, the excel.exe process does not get closed.
In fact, Excel will leave an Excel.exe process open for each file that you right-click > print.

I tested this on 2 different workstations set up this way, and both behaved the same way.  Both Windows and MS Office have been fully updated.

This is an issue as one of our users prints a lot of excel docs and eventually runs out of memory on the VM due to all of the leftover Excel.exe processes.

I did find that if you open Excel first and just minimize it, and then right-click > print the .xlsx files you need to print, the Excel.exe processes close properly when they are done being printed.

The workaround works for now, however it would be great if anyone knows of a way to fix this permanently.

Ticket.description:
We are having issues adding a second Connection Broker to our system.

Server configurations:

1 - RDS-Connection Broker - Windows 2012 R2


3 - RDS- Session Hosts - Windows 2012 R2


1 - Machine we want to add RDS-CB to (RDS-MGR) and is running the SQL Express 2016 for the HA and the OS is Windows 2012 R2.

This all started because we were wanting to move the RDS-CB off of the server it is currently on.  (Current server is the DC).  So through some investigating we found that the best way to do this is to set up the HA, add the new server, then remove the existing server.  We have followed the information at this link: https://thewolfblog.com/2014/02/02/configuring-ha-for-the-remote-desktop-connection-broker/ to a "T" (as well as a few others that were pretty well the same with slight differences).  We have been successful in getting the HA configured and the database moved to the SQL Express 2016.  We are having issues getting the new server added as a broker now.  We are getting an error:


"The database specified in the connection string Driver=SQL Server Native Client 11.0;SERVER=RDS-MGR\RDSQL;Trusted_Connection=Yes;APP=Remote Desktop Services Connection Broker;DATABASE=RDSQL is not available from the RD Connection Broker server RDS-MGR.domain.  Ensure that the database server is available on the network, the SQL Server Native Client is installed on all RD Connection Broker servers, and the computer accounts of the RD Connection Broker servers are members of the RDS Management Servers group on the database server."


We have created a new separate test server to see if it can be configured as an RDS CB server, and it gets the same error when trying to add it. 


The original CB server and the two new servers all have the SQL client on them and all pass the connection test when going through the ODBC configuration.  Firewall has been turned off on all involved servers to ensure that it is not interfering.  The test server and new server have been rebooted several times (cannot reboot the original server right now).  We have checked that the servers are added to the AD security group that is used in the SQL authentication.

We cannot figure out why this is not connecting.


Any assistance will be greatly appreciated.

Ticket.description:
This is a weird one...we use a system to manage passwords so admins don't ever actually have their passwords for their privileged accounts, and it grants access to their resources via RDP sessions to a terminal server which launches an application on login without launching the desktop.

Usually, this works fine.

Frequently enough, though (usually get at least a couple reports per day), after logging in to the server, the userinit.exe program will get an "Access is denied" error trying to launch the initial program.  The login itself is successful as I can open Task Manager and use it to launch Windows Explorer; I can even manually launch the program itself without problems at that point.

Ticket.description: I have a couple users in a 300+ user environment that are having issues printing from word or outlook or even notepad. When they go to print, upon hitting print the program freezes. When you open the devices and printer window, it takes for ever to load and then it hangs at the end. I've found that when trying to restart the print spooler it comes up with an error 1053: the service did not respond. I've tried enabling the Bluetooth support service and set it to run automatically but that doesn't work. I also found out that you have to try and load the printers and devices, open up the services and attempt to restart the print spooler, wait for it to timeout, refresh the printer and devices window, start the print spooler and then do it all again one more time for it to fix the issue. I'm looking for a permanent fix to this issue. I've tried imagining the computer even reinstalling it from scratch but the error keeps coming back.

Ticket.description:
Alrighty everyone, here's the situation.

We've got a couple of Windows 10 pro computers, running a second copy of Windows 10 pro within a Hyper-V virtual machine that's connected to a different domain.  Both the host machine, and the VM have Office 2016 installed via an Office 365 subscription.

On the host machine, when we right-click on an .xlsx file and select 'print', the Excel file prints successfully to the default printer and if you look in the process list, the Excel.exe process that opens during the print, closes successfully.

However, on the VM, if you attempt the same thing, the excel.exe process does not get closed.
In fact, Excel will leave an Excel.exe process open for each file that you right-click > print.

I tested this on 2 different workstations set up this way, and both behaved the same way.  Both Windows and MS Office have been fully updated.

This is an issue as one of our users prints a lot of excel docs and eventually runs out of memory on the VM due to all of the leftover Excel.exe processes.

I did find that if you open Excel first and just minimize it, and then right-click > print the .xlsx files you need to print, the Excel.exe processes close properly when they are done being printed.

The workaround works for now, however it would be great if anyone knows of a way to fix this permanently.

Ticket.description:
We are having issues adding a second Connection Broker to our system.

Server configurations:

1 - RDS-Connection Broker - Windows 2012 R2


3 - RDS- Session Hosts - Windows 2012 R2


1 - Machine we want to add RDS-CB to (RDS-MGR) and is running the SQL Express 2016 for the HA and the OS is Windows 2012 R2.

This all started because we were wanting to move the RDS-CB off of the server it is currently on.  (Current server is the DC).  So through some investigating we found that the best way to do this is to set up the HA, add the new server, then remove the existing server.  We have followed the information at this link: https://thewolfblog.com/2014/02/02/configuring-ha-for-the-remote-desktop-connection-broker/ to a "T" (as well as a few others that were pretty well the same with slight differences).  We have been successful in getting the HA configured and the database moved to the SQL Express 2016.  We are having issues getting the new server added as a broker now.  We are getting an error:


"The database specified in the connection string Driver=SQL Server Native Client 11.0;SERVER=RDS-MGR\RDSQL;Trusted_Connection=Yes;APP=Remote Desktop Services Connection Broker;DATABASE=RDSQL is not available from the RD Connection Broker server RDS-MGR.domain.  Ensure that the database server is available on the network, the SQL Server Native Client is installed on all RD Connection Broker servers, and the computer accounts of the RD Connection Broker servers are members of the RDS Management Servers group on the database server."


We have created a new separate test server to see if it can be configured as an RDS CB server, and it gets the same error when trying to add it. 


The original CB server and the two new servers all have the SQL client on them and all pass the connection test when going through the ODBC configuration.  Firewall has been turned off on all involved servers to ensure that it is not interfering.  The test server and new server have been rebooted several times (cannot reboot the original server right now).  We have checked that the servers are added to the AD security group that is used in the SQL authentication.

We cannot figure out why this is not connecting.


Any assistance will be greatly appreciated.

Ticket.description: I have a couple users in a 300+ user environment that are having issues printing from word or outlook or even notepad. When they go to print, upon hitting print the program freezes. When you open the devices and printer window, it takes for ever to load and then it hangs at the end. I've found that when trying to restart the print spooler it comes up with an error 1053: the service did not respond. I've tried enabling the Bluetooth support service and set it to run automatically but that doesn't work. I also found out that you have to try and load the printers and devices, open up the services and attempt to restart the print spooler, wait for it to timeout, refresh the printer and devices window, start the print spooler and then do it all again one more time for it to fix the issue. I'm looking for a permanent fix to this issue. I've tried imagining the computer even reinstalling it from scratch but the error keeps coming back.

Ticket.description:
Alrighty everyone, here's the situation.

We've got a couple of Windows 10 pro computers, running a second copy of Windows 10 pro within a Hyper-V virtual machine that's connected to a different domain.  Both the host machine, and the VM have Office 2016 installed via an Office 365 subscription.

On the host machine, when we right-click on an .xlsx file and select 'print', the Excel file prints successfully to the default printer and if you look in the process list, the Excel.exe process that opens during the print, closes successfully.

However, on the VM, if you attempt the same thing, the excel.exe process does not get closed.
In fact, Excel will leave an Excel.exe process open for each file that you right-click > print.

I tested this on 2 different workstations set up this way, and both behaved the same way.  Both Windows and MS Office have been fully updated.

This is an issue as one of our users prints a lot of excel docs and eventually runs out of memory on the VM due to all of the leftover Excel.exe processes.

I did find that if you open Excel first and just minimize it, and then right-click > print the .xlsx files you need to print, the Excel.exe processes close properly when they are done being printed.

The workaround works for now, however it would be great if anyone knows of a way to fix this permanently.

This all started because we were wanting to move the RDS-CB off of the server it is currently on.  (Current server is the DC).  So through some investigating we found that the best way to do this is to set up the HA, add the new server, then remove the existing server.  We have followed the information at this link: https://thewolfblog.com/2014/02/02/configuring-ha-for-the-remote-desktop-connection-broker/ to a "T" (as well as a few others that were pretty well the same with slight differences).  We have been successful in getting the HA configured and the database moved to the SQL Express 2016.  We are having issues getting the new server added as a broker now.  We are getting an error:


"The database specified in the connection string Driver=SQL Server Native Client 11.0;SERVER=RDS-MGR\RDSQL;Trusted_Connection=Yes;APP=Remote Desktop Services Connection Broker;DATABASE=RDSQL is not available from the RD Connection Broker server RDS-MGR.domain.  Ensure that the database server is available on the network, the SQL Server Native Client is installed on all RD Connection Broker servers, and the computer accounts of the RD Connection Broker servers are members of the RDS Management Servers group on the database server."


We have created a new separate test server to see if it can be configured as an RDS CB server, and it gets the same error when trying to add it. 


The original CB server and the two new servers all have the SQL client on them and all pass the connection test when going through the ODBC configuration.  Firewall has been turned off on all involved servers to ensure that it is not interfering.  The test server and new server have been rebooted several times (cannot reboot the original server right now).  We have checked that the servers are added to the AD security group that is used in the SQL authentication.

We cannot figure out why this is not connecting.


Any assistance will be greatly appreciated.

Ticket.description:
Hello all,

In the process of adding a new larger RAID to our server.  Set-up is a Dell PE T610 running Server 2008 R2 on the physical machine hosting a 2012 R2 Essentials VM through HyperV.  Currently has a PERC H200 card and 4TB RAID10 that I'm replacing with am H710 card and 8TB RAID10.  Due to changing controller cards (and purposely not attempting the unsupported foreign config import from the H200 to H710), and wanting to be able to completely revert back to the old setup if things go sideways, my only option is to copy the VM to an external USB drive, disconnect the old RAID, connect the new RAID, copy the VM back to the new RAID.

The big question is, HOW to do this exactly.  And what is the most reliable and least complicated method.  I've been reading everything I can find, but there is precious little info on re-importing a VM to the exact same physical host.  I know simply copying the .vhd files to the new RAID and pointing the VM to them does not work.  The only other things I've been able to ascertain are:

1)  I can re-import the exact same VM to the new location, but FIRST I have to delete the old VM from HYPV manager.  I'm not comfortable doing this.

2)  I can import the VM as a NEW VM.  I'm concerned about all of the issues that might crop up with having a new VM.  For instanc, I remember reading something about an issue with the virtual network card and MAC address.  Will I have to reconnect all of the client computers?  Will I have to re-set-up remote web access/remote client access? 


I guess I'm hoping there's away to accomplish option 1 without having to permanently delete the old VM.  I'm open to any suggestions!

Ticket.description:
So we have a two node 2012 R2 Cluster. We are using Starwinds for shared storage. We have 10 VM roles, 1 dhcp server role and 3 Scale out file server Roles.


Our goal is to provide maximum up time for the VM's and some important file shares.  The file share data is actually more important than the VM's. The shares are users, projects and operations.  Each share is 1.5 TB max with around 300GB used on each one.


Not sure why, but when we originally designed this, Starwinds highly recommended that we create the file shares using the scale out file server role vs using the standard file server role or creating a "VM File server" to share the files.  So right now each of the shares is on a SOFS Role and shared to the users from there. From everything I've read this is NOT the way file server user shares should be setup. See when to use a SOFS. The system currently works and fails over without issues but we're having issues to trying to backup the files. The VM's backup fine with no issues with just about any backup software. The problem is the file share data. Most backup software doesn't support MS clusters or doesn't work with SMB 3.0 or has some other little issue that makes it not work reliably or runs slower than I can deal with. Veeam file copy works but it's so slow. We're getting like 2MB/sec.  


Finally my question. What is the proper way to set this up to make backing up easy? Preferably with Veeam. We want to keep one or two copies onsite and one offsite. Spinning up the environment offsite would be great but is not mandatory, maybe something we can do in the future.


Because nearly all backup software is geared towards backing up VM's these days (not the files on the file share), my gut tells me to just create a VM and share the files from the VM. The problem with that is the VM's become huge (3x1.5 TB) and will take forever to migrate and restore. The current VM's are around 50GB and restore or migrate very quickly.


Any help would be greatly appreciated.
Ticket.message: Sounds like a hardware or driver problem. try a different wlanic, or try to get the newest driver for the current one from the web.

Ticket.description:
I'm working on doing a server migration and running into some weird issues that I was hoping I could get some advice on.  Here is all the information in regards to the setup, old and new, and what has happened thus far.

Old server: Windows server 2012 essentials: Domain controller, file and printer server.

New Server: Vmware 6.5 running a vm of windows server 2012 r2 standard.

I started off by moving files over. Once that transfer completed, I  began by adding the new server to the domain. It was added successfully. I then installed the roles on the new server and after a restart, followed the steps to promote the server to be an AD server. I then proceeded to transfer the 5 fsmo roles, and afterwards running netdom query fsmo showed all the roles assigned to the new server. In the past at this point I've been able to remove the server from the network, update dns, and proceed with the setup. However this is the point where I hit a wall. AD logins stopped responding once the old server was removed, and the new server was not indicating on the network card that it was linked to a domain network, even though the primary dns was pointed at itself. Everything appeared to be working properly from a settings perspective, but other pcs showed the echo %logonserver% as the old server, and attempting to RDP into the new server with domain credentials resulted in an error indicating it could not contact the domain controller. Reconnecting the old server resulted in things working properly again, so to me this seems to indicate the AD transfer didn't complete, even though all signs pointed to it completing. Ticket.description:
At my company, we have folder redirection enabled for all users so their desktops, documents, etc are all stored on our file server. Additionally, our users with laptops and Surfaces (all Windows 8.1 or 10) have offline files enabled so their redirected folders are available when they're off-network.

We're in the process of replacing our SAN and moving everything over to the new one. For reasons unknown to me, our old "file server" was not a Windows VM, but instead just a share running directly off the old SAN, meaning that just moving a VM or using DFS replication to copy all the data was not a possibility.

So over the weekend I used Robocopy to copy all the data off the old SAN share onto a new Windows 2012 R2 virtual machine. I verified everything copied over, verified all the permissions and ACLs were correct, etc. Then I switched the GPOs for folder redirection and our network share mappings to point to the new server.

As a precautionary measure, since the GPOs were pointed directly to the old SAN (\\san\shares\users\%username%; \\san\shares\departments\%something%; etc), we disabled the shares on the old SAN, so that clients that didn't update their paths correctly wouldn't be writing to a stale location.

This worked fine for our desktop computers - except for a few minor hiccups, our desktops are all connecting to the new SAN, redirection and shares are working good, etc.

Our portable devices though are not cooperating quite as well. We've had a number of them still trying to connect to the old SAN, not getting the updated redirection/share paths, and just staying in a perpetual "offline" mode. To counter this, we tried removing the DNS record for the old SAN and replacing it with a CNAME pointing to the new file server, so that portable devices trying to connect to the old SAN would redirect to the new one and hopefully sync their files, but the Offline Files is still seeming to remain in an offline state, even though pinging the old SAN's name returns the correct IP of the new file server.

Ticket.description:
Hello all,

In the process of adding a new larger RAID to our server.  Set-up is a Dell PE T610 running Server 2008 R2 on the physical machine hosting a 2012 R2 Essentials VM through HyperV.  Currently has a PERC H200 card and 4TB RAID10 that I'm replacing with am H710 card and 8TB RAID10.  Due to changing controller cards (and purposely not attempting the unsupported foreign config import from the H200 to H710), and wanting to be able to completely revert back to the old setup if things go sideways, my only option is to copy the VM to an external USB drive, disconnect the old RAID, connect the new RAID, copy the VM back to the new RAID.

The big question is, HOW to do this exactly.  And what is the most reliable and least complicated method.  I've been reading everything I can find, but there is precious little info on re-importing a VM to the exact same physical host.  I know simply copying the .vhd files to the new RAID and pointing the VM to them does not work.  The only other things I've been able to ascertain are:

1)  I can re-import the exact same VM to the new location, but FIRST I have to delete the old VM from HYPV manager.  I'm not comfortable doing this.

2)  I can import the VM as a NEW VM.  I'm concerned about all of the issues that might crop up with having a new VM.  For instanc, I remember reading something about an issue with the virtual network card and MAC address.  Will I have to reconnect all of the client computers?  Will I have to re-set-up remote web access/remote client access? 


I guess I'm hoping there's away to accomplish option 1 without having to permanently delete the old VM.  I'm open to any suggestions!

Ticket.description:
So we have a two node 2012 R2 Cluster. We are using Starwinds for shared storage. We have 10 VM roles, 1 dhcp server role and 3 Scale out file server Roles.


Our goal is to provide maximum up time for the VM's and some important file shares.  The file share data is actually more important than the VM's. The shares are users, projects and operations.  Each share is 1.5 TB max with around 300GB used on each one.


Not sure why, but when we originally designed this, Starwinds highly recommended that we create the file shares using the scale out file server role vs using the standard file server role or creating a "VM File server" to share the files.  So right now each of the shares is on a SOFS Role and shared to the users from there. From everything I've read this is NOT the way file server user shares should be setup. See when to use a SOFS. The system currently works and fails over without issues but we're having issues to trying to backup the files. The VM's backup fine with no issues with just about any backup software. The problem is the file share data. Most backup software doesn't support MS clusters or doesn't work with SMB 3.0 or has some other little issue that makes it not work reliably or runs slower than I can deal with. Veeam file copy works but it's so slow. We're getting like 2MB/sec.  


Finally my question. What is the proper way to set this up to make backing up easy? Preferably with Veeam. We want to keep one or two copies onsite and one offsite. Spinning up the environment offsite would be great but is not mandatory, maybe something we can do in the future.


Because nearly all backup software is geared towards backing up VM's these days (not the files on the file share), my gut tells me to just create a VM and share the files from the VM. The problem with that is the VM's become huge (3x1.5 TB) and will take forever to migrate and restore. The current VM's are around 50GB and restore or migrate very quickly.


Any help would be greatly appreciated.

Ticket.description:
I'm working on doing a server migration and running into some weird issues that I was hoping I could get some advice on.  Here is all the information in regards to the setup, old and new, and what has happened thus far.

Old server: Windows server 2012 essentials: Domain controller, file and printer server.

New Server: Vmware 6.5 running a vm of windows server 2012 r2 standard.

I started off by moving files over. Once that transfer completed, I  began by adding the new server to the domain. It was added successfully. I then installed the roles on the new server and after a restart, followed the steps to promote the server to be an AD server. I then proceeded to transfer the 5 fsmo roles, and afterwards running netdom query fsmo showed all the roles assigned to the new server. In the past at this point I've been able to remove the server from the network, update dns, and proceed with the setup. However this is the point where I hit a wall. AD logins stopped responding once the old server was removed, and the new server was not indicating on the network card that it was linked to a domain network, even though the primary dns was pointed at itself. Everything appeared to be working properly from a settings perspective, but other pcs showed the echo %logonserver% as the old server, and attempting to RDP into the new server with domain credentials resulted in an error indicating it could not contact the domain controller. Reconnecting the old server resulted in things working properly again, so to me this seems to indicate the AD transfer didn't complete, even though all signs pointed to it completing. I had to transfer the fsmo roles back and then I attempted again later, still getting the same error. At this point I'm reformatting the new server install and starting over again, but wanted to get any advice on what issue I may be running into.

Ticket.description:
Hello all,

In the process of adding a new larger RAID to our server.  Set-up is a Dell PE T610 running Server 2008 R2 on the physical machine hosting a 2012 R2 Essentials VM through HyperV.  Currently has a PERC H200 card and 4TB RAID10 that I'm replacing with am H710 card and 8TB RAID10.  Due to changing controller cards (and purposely not attempting the unsupported foreign config import from the H200 to H710), and wanting to be able to completely revert back to the old setup if things go sideways, my only option is to copy the VM to an external USB drive, disconnect the old RAID, connect the new RAID, copy the VM back to the new RAID.

The big question is, HOW to do this exactly.  And what is the most reliable and least complicated method.  I've been reading everything I can find, but there is precious little info on re-importing a VM to the exact same physical host.  I know simply copying the .vhd files to the new RAID and pointing the VM to them does not work.  The only other things I've been able to ascertain are:

1)  I can re-import the exact same VM to the new location, but FIRST I have to delete the old VM from HYPV manager.  I'm not comfortable doing this.

2)  I can import the VM as a NEW VM.  I'm concerned about all of the issues that might crop up with having a new VM.  For instanc, I remember reading something about an issue with the virtual network card and MAC address.  Will I have to reconnect all of the client computers?  Will I have to re-set-up remote web access/remote client access? 


I guess I'm hoping there's away to accomplish option 1 without having to permanently delete the old VM.  I'm open to any suggestions!

Ticket.description:
So we have a two node 2012 R2 Cluster. We are using Starwinds for shared storage. We have 10 VM roles, 1 dhcp server role and 3 Scale out file server Roles.


Our goal is to provide maximum up time for the VM's and some important file shares.  The file share data is actually more important than the VM's. The shares are users, projects and operations.  Each share is 1.5 TB max with around 300GB used on each one.


Not sure why, but when we originally designed this, Starwinds highly recommended that we create the file shares using the scale out file server role vs using the standard file server role or creating a "VM File server" to share the files.  So right now each of the shares is on a SOFS Role and shared to the users from there. From everything I've read this is NOT the way file server user shares should be setup. See when to use a SOFS. The system currently works and fails over without issues but we're having issues to trying to backup the files. The VM's backup fine with no issues with just about any backup software. The problem is the file share data. Most backup software doesn't support MS clusters or doesn't work with SMB 3.0 or has some other little issue that makes it not work reliably or runs slower than I can deal with. Veeam file copy works but it's so slow. We're getting like 2MB/sec.  


Finally my question. What is the proper way to set this up to make backing up easy? Preferably with Veeam. We want to keep one or two copies onsite and one offsite. Spinning up the environment offsite would be great but is not mandatory, maybe something we can do in the future.


Because nearly all backup software is geared towards backing up VM's these days (not the files on the file share), my gut tells me to just create a VM and share the files from the VM. The problem with that is the VM's become huge (3x1.5 TB) and will take forever to migrate and restore. The current VM's are around 50GB and restore or migrate very quickly.


Any help would be greatly appreciated.

Ticket.description:
I'm working on doing a server migration and running into some weird issues that I was hoping I could get some advice on.  Here is all the information in regards to the setup, old and new, and what has happened thus far.

Old server: Windows server 2012 essentials: Domain controller, file and printer server.

New Server: Vmware 6.5 running a vm of windows server 2012 r2 standard.

I started off by moving files over. Once that transfer completed, I  began by adding the new server to the domain. It was added successfully. I then installed the roles on the new server and after a restart, followed the steps to promote the server to be an AD server. I then proceeded to transfer the 5 fsmo roles, and afterwards running netdom query fsmo showed all the roles assigned to the new server. In the past at this point I've been able to remove the server from the network, update dns, and proceed with the setup. However this is the point where I hit a wall. AD logins stopped responding once the old server was removed, and the new server was not indicating on the network card that it was linked to a domain network, even though the primary dns was pointed at itself. Everything appeared to be working properly from a settings perspective, but other pcs showed the echo %logonserver% as the old server, and attempting to RDP into the new server with domain credentials resulted in an error indicating it could not contact the domain controller. Reconnecting the old server resulted in things working properly again, so to me this seems to indicate the AD transfer didn't complete, even though all signs pointed to it completing. I had to transfer the fsmo roles back and then I attempted again later, still getting the same error. At this point I'm reformatting the new server install and starting over again, but wanted to get any advice on what issue I may be running into.

Ticket.description:
At my company, we have folder redirection enabled for all users so their desktops, documents, etc are all stored on our file server. Additionally, our users with laptops and Surfaces (all Windows 8.1 or 10) have offline files enabled so their redirected folders are available when they're off-network.

We're in the process of replacing our SAN and moving everything over to the new one. For reasons unknown to me, our old "file server" was not a Windows VM, but instead just a share running directly off the old SAN, meaning that just moving a VM or using DFS replication to copy all the data was not a possibility.

So over the weekend I used Robocopy to copy all the data off the old SAN share onto a new Windows 2012 R2 virtual machine. I verified everything copied over, verified all the permissions and ACLs were correct, etc. Then I switched the GPOs for folder redirection and our network share mappings to point to the new server.

As a precautionary measure, since the GPOs were pointed directly to the old SAN (\\san\shares\users\%username%; \\san\shares\departments\%something%; etc), we disabled the shares on the old SAN, so that clients that didn't update their paths correctly wouldn't be writing to a stale location.

This worked fine for our desktop computers - except for a few minor hiccups, our desktops are all connecting to the new SAN, redirection and shares are working good, etc.

Our portable devices though are not cooperating quite as well. We've had a number of them still trying to connect to the old SAN, not getting the updated redirection/share paths, and just staying in a perpetual "offline" mode. To counter this, we tried removing the DNS record for the old SAN and replacing it with a CNAME pointing to the new file server, so that portable devices trying to connect to the old SAN would redirect to the new one and hopefully sync their files, but the Offline Files is still seeming to remain in an offline state, even though pinging the old SAN's name returns the correct IP of the new file server.

Ticket.description:
Hello all,

In the process of adding a new larger RAID to our server.  Set-up is a Dell PE T610 running Server 2008 R2 on the physical machine hosting a 2012 R2 Essentials VM through HyperV.  Currently has a PERC H200 card and 4TB RAID10 that I'm replacing with am H710 card and 8TB RAID10.  Due to changing controller cards (and purposely not attempting the unsupported foreign config import from the H200 to H710), and wanting to be able to completely revert back to the old setup if things go sideways, my only option is to copy the VM to an external USB drive, disconnect the old RAID, connect the new RAID, copy the VM back to the new RAID.

The big question is, HOW to do this exactly.  And what is the most reliable and least complicated method.  I've been reading everything I can find, but there is precious little info on re-importing a VM to the exact same physical host.  I know simply copying the .vhd files to the new RAID and pointing the VM to them does not work.  The only other things I've been able to ascertain are:

1)  I can re-import the exact same VM to the new location, but FIRST I have to delete the old VM from HYPV manager.  I'm not comfortable doing this.

2)  I can import the VM as a NEW VM.  I'm concerned about all of the issues that might crop up with having a new VM.  For instanc, I remember reading something about an issue with the virtual network card and MAC address.  Will I have to reconnect all of the client computers?  Will I have to re-set-up remote web access/remote client access? 


I guess I'm hoping there's away to accomplish option 1 without having to permanently delete the old VM.  I'm open to any suggestions!

Ticket.description:
So we have a two node 2012 R2 Cluster. We are using Starwinds for shared storage. We have 10 VM roles, 1 dhcp server role and 3 Scale out file server Roles.


Our goal is to provide maximum up time for the VM's and some important file shares.  The file share data is actually more important than the VM's. The shares are users, projects and operations.  Each share is 1.5 TB max with around 300GB used on each one.


Not sure why, but when we originally designed this, Starwinds highly recommended that we create the file shares using the scale out file server role vs using the standard file server role or creating a "VM File server" to share the files.  So right now each of the shares is on a SOFS Role and shared to the users from there. From everything I've read this is NOT the way file server user shares should be setup. See when to use a SOFS. The system currently works and fails over without issues but we're having issues to trying to backup the files. The VM's backup fine with no issues with just about any backup software. The problem is the file share data. Most backup software doesn't support MS clusters or doesn't work with SMB 3.0 or has some other little issue that makes it not work reliably or runs slower than I can deal with. Veeam file copy works but it's so slow. We're getting like 2MB/sec.  


Finally my question. What is the proper way to set this up to make backing up easy? Preferably with Veeam. We want to keep one or two copies onsite and one offsite. Spinning up the environment offsite would be great but is not mandatory, maybe something we can do in the future.


Because nearly all backup software is geared towards backing up VM's these days (not the files on the file share), my gut tells me to just create a VM and share the files from the VM. The problem with that is the VM's become huge (3x1.5 TB) and will take forever to migrate and restore. The current VM's are around 50GB and restore or migrate very quickly.


Any help would be greatly appreciated.
Ticket.message: I should also mention that wired ethernet works fine, it's just the wireless on the machine that has the issues.

Ticket.description:
I'm working on doing a server migration and running into some weird issues that I was hoping I could get some advice on.  Here is all the information in regards to the setup, old and new, and what has happened thus far.

Old server: Windows server 2012 essentials: Domain controller, file and printer server.

New Server: Vmware 6.5 running a vm of windows server 2012 r2 standard.

I started off by moving files over. Once that transfer completed, I  began by adding the new server to the domain. It was added successfully. I then installed the roles on the new server and after a restart, followed the steps to promote the server to be an AD server. I then proceeded to transfer the 5 fsmo roles, and afterwards running netdom query fsmo showed all the roles assigned to the new server. In the past at this point I've been able to remove the server from the network, update dns, and proceed with the setup. However this is the point where I hit a wall. AD logins stopped responding once the old server was removed, and the new server was not indicating on the network card that it was linked to a domain network, even though the primary dns was pointed at itself. Everything appeared to be working properly from a settings perspective, but other pcs showed the echo %logonserver% as the old server, and attempting to RDP into the new server with domain credentials resulted in an error indicating it could not contact the domain controller. Reconnecting the old server resulted in things working properly again, so to me this seems to indicate the AD transfer didn't complete, even though all signs pointed to it completing. I had to transfer the fsmo roles back and then I attempted again later, still getting the same error. At this point I'm reformatting the new server install and starting over again, but wanted to get any advice on what issue I may be running into.

Ticket.description:
At my company, we have folder redirection enabled for all users so their desktops, documents, etc are all stored on our file server. Additionally, our users with laptops and Surfaces (all Windows 8.1 or 10) have offline files enabled so their redirected folders are available when they're off-network.

We're in the process of replacing our SAN and moving everything over to the new one. For reasons unknown to me, our old "file server" was not a Windows VM, but instead just a share running directly off the old SAN, meaning that just moving a VM or using DFS replication to copy all the data was not a possibility.

So over the weekend I used Robocopy to copy all the data off the old SAN share onto a new Windows 2012 R2 virtual machine. I verified everything copied over, verified all the permissions and ACLs were correct, etc. Then I switched the GPOs for folder redirection and our network share mappings to point to the new server.

As a precautionary measure, since the GPOs were pointed directly to the old SAN (\\san\shares\users\%username%; \\san\shares\departments\%something%; etc), we disabled the shares on the old SAN, so that clients that didn't update their paths correctly wouldn't be writing to a stale location.

This worked fine for our desktop computers - except for a few minor hiccups, our desktops are all connecting to the new SAN, redirection and shares are working good, etc.

Our portable devices though are not cooperating quite as well. We've had a number of them still trying to connect to the old SAN, not getting the updated redirection/share paths, and just staying in a perpetual "offline" mode. To counter this, we tried removing the DNS record for the old SAN and replacing it with a CNAME pointing to the new file server, so that portable devices trying to connect to the old SAN would redirect to the new one and hopefully sync their files, but the Offline Files is still seeming to remain in an offline state, even though pinging the old SAN's name returns the correct IP of the new file server.
Ticket.message: I should also mention that wired ethernet works fine, it's just the wireless on the machine that has the issues.

In the process of adding a new larger RAID to our server.  Set-up is a Dell PE T610 running Server 2008 R2 on the physical machine hosting a 2012 R2 Essentials VM through HyperV.  Currently has a PERC H200 card and 4TB RAID10 that I'm replacing with am H710 card and 8TB RAID10.  Due to changing controller cards (and purposely not attempting the unsupported foreign config import from the H200 to H710), and wanting to be able to completely revert back to the old setup if things go sideways, my only option is to copy the VM to an external USB drive, disconnect the old RAID, connect the new RAID, copy the VM back to the new RAID.

The big question is, HOW to do this exactly.  And what is the most reliable and least complicated method.  I've been reading everything I can find, but there is precious little info on re-importing a VM to the exact same physical host.  I know simply copying the .vhd files to the new RAID and pointing the VM to them does not work.  The only other things I've been able to ascertain are:

1)  I can re-import the exact same VM to the new location, but FIRST I have to delete the old VM from HYPV manager.  I'm not comfortable doing this.

2)  I can import the VM as a NEW VM.  I'm concerned about all of the issues that might crop up with having a new VM.  For instanc, I remember reading something about an issue with the virtual network card and MAC address.  Will I have to reconnect all of the client computers?  Will I have to re-set-up remote web access/remote client access? 


I guess I'm hoping there's away to accomplish option 1 without having to permanently delete the old VM.  I'm open to any suggestions!

Ticket.description:
So we have a two node 2012 R2 Cluster. We are using Starwinds for shared storage. We have 10 VM roles, 1 dhcp server role and 3 Scale out file server Roles.


Our goal is to provide maximum up time for the VM's and some important file shares.  The file share data is actually more important than the VM's. The shares are users, projects and operations.  Each share is 1.5 TB max with around 300GB used on each one.


Not sure why, but when we originally designed this, Starwinds highly recommended that we create the file shares using the scale out file server role vs using the standard file server role or creating a "VM File server" to share the files.  So right now each of the shares is on a SOFS Role and shared to the users from there. From everything I've read this is NOT the way file server user shares should be setup. See when to use a SOFS. The system currently works and fails over without issues but we're having issues to trying to backup the files. The VM's backup fine with no issues with just about any backup software. The problem is the file share data. Most backup software doesn't support MS clusters or doesn't work with SMB 3.0 or has some other little issue that makes it not work reliably or runs slower than I can deal with. Veeam file copy works but it's so slow. We're getting like 2MB/sec.  


Finally my question. What is the proper way to set this up to make backing up easy? Preferably with Veeam. We want to keep one or two copies onsite and one offsite. Spinning up the environment offsite would be great but is not mandatory, maybe something we can do in the future.


Because nearly all backup software is geared towards backing up VM's these days (not the files on the file share), my gut tells me to just create a VM and share the files from the VM. The problem with that is the VM's become huge (3x1.5 TB) and will take forever to migrate and restore. The current VM's are around 50GB and restore or migrate very quickly.


Any help would be greatly appreciated.

Ticket.description:
I'm working on doing a server migration and running into some weird issues that I was hoping I could get some advice on.  Here is all the information in regards to the setup, old and new, and what has happened thus far.

Old server: Windows server 2012 essentials: Domain controller, file and printer server.

New Server: Vmware 6.5 running a vm of windows server 2012 r2 standard.

I started off by moving files over. Once that transfer completed, I  began by adding the new server to the domain. It was added successfully. I then installed the roles on the new server and after a restart, followed the steps to promote the server to be an AD server. I then proceeded to transfer the 5 fsmo roles, and afterwards running netdom query fsmo showed all the roles assigned to the new server. In the past at this point I've been able to remove the server from the network, update dns, and proceed with the setup. However this is the point where I hit a wall. AD logins stopped responding once the old server was removed, and the new server was not indicating on the network card that it was linked to a domain network, even though the primary dns was pointed at itself. Everything appeared to be working properly from a settings perspective, but other pcs showed the echo %logonserver% as the old server, and attempting to RDP into the new server with domain credentials resulted in an error indicating it could not contact the domain controller. Reconnecting the old server resulted in things working properly again, so to me this seems to indicate the AD transfer didn't complete, even though all signs pointed to it completing. I had to transfer the fsmo roles back and then I attempted again later, still getting the same error. At this point I'm reformatting the new server install and starting over again, but wanted to get any advice on what issue I may be running into.

Ticket.description:
At my company, we have folder redirection enabled for all users so their desktops, documents, etc are all stored on our file server. Additionally, our users with laptops and Surfaces (all Windows 8.1 or 10) have offline files enabled so their redirected folders are available when they're off-network.

We're in the process of replacing our SAN and moving everything over to the new one. For reasons unknown to me, our old "file server" was not a Windows VM, but instead just a share running directly off the old SAN, meaning that just moving a VM or using DFS replication to copy all the data was not a possibility.

So over the weekend I used Robocopy to copy all the data off the old SAN share onto a new Windows 2012 R2 virtual machine. I verified everything copied over, verified all the permissions and ACLs were correct, etc. Then I switched the GPOs for folder redirection and our network share mappings to point to the new server.

As a precautionary measure, since the GPOs were pointed directly to the old SAN (\\san\shares\users\%username%; \\san\shares\departments\%something%; etc), we disabled the shares on the old SAN, so that clients that didn't update their paths correctly wouldn't be writing to a stale location.

This worked fine for our desktop computers - except for a few minor hiccups, our desktops are all connecting to the new SAN, redirection and shares are working good, etc.

Our portable devices though are not cooperating quite as well. We've had a number of them still trying to connect to the old SAN, not getting the updated redirection/share paths, and just staying in a perpetual "offline" mode. To counter this, we tried removing the DNS record for the old SAN and replacing it with a CNAME pointing to the new file server, so that portable devices trying to connect to the old SAN would redirect to the new one and hopefully sync their files, but the Offline Files is still seeming to remain in an offline state, even though pinging the old SAN's name returns the correct IP of the new file server.

Ticket.message:
Dear Raju R

 

Does the same WLAN NIC work on a different system without issue? If so, check the driver and driver version for the wireless NIC on the working and non-working system. If it doesn't work on a different system or any others, then it's an issue with the WLAN NIC - likely software configuration.

If static IP doesn't allow you to ping the default GW over wireless but the system appears to be connected to the wireless network, check the event logs on the Windows host to see if there is any more details there. Also ensure the WLAN NIC is compatible with whatever wireless you are broadcasting (ie: if broadcasting 802.11g, ensure the WLAN NIC supports 802.11g).

When a user logs into a Windows 7 machine, it adds folders to the start menu with shortcuts to specific websites. There are a few folders that have the same URL as other folders. Product 2URL 1 

We've noticed in our Windows 10 (1709) machines that it only list duplicate URLs once. Even if the URL shortcuts have different names, it will only show one shortcut to the website instead of the many shortcuts of the same URL with different names. 

Am I missing something? Is this intention and if so, does anyone know a way around this?

Ticket.description: I have some users that are running some very resource intensive processes which often consume many GBs worth of RAM. Often times a user will run a job which ends up consuming close to 100% of the system's RAM (which in our case is around 100GB). The issue in our case, is the disparity between what the user sees reported in Task Manager vs what I (the admin) see reported in Resource Monitor. Task Monitor is reporting that the user's process is using 1.3GB of RAM while Resource Monitor reports the process has 3.7GB committed to memory and 100GB in working memory. Because the user is not able to see this memory issue in Task Manager, they assume the issue is caused by other users on the VM. Without having admin privileges, are there any good ways for a user to view more info on their RAM usage?

Ticket.description:
Hello all,

In the process of adding a new larger RAID to our server.  Set-up is a Dell PE T610 running Server 2008 R2 on the physical machine hosting a 2012 R2 Essentials VM through HyperV.  Currently has a PERC H200 card and 4TB RAID10 that I'm replacing with am H710 card and 8TB RAID10.  Due to changing controller cards (and purposely not attempting the unsupported foreign config import from the H200 to H710), and wanting to be able to completely revert back to the old setup if things go sideways, my only option is to copy the VM to an external USB drive, disconnect the old RAID, connect the new RAID, copy the VM back to the new RAID.

The big question is, HOW to do this exactly.  And what is the most reliable and least complicated method.  I've been reading everything I can find, but there is precious little info on re-importing a VM to the exact same physical host.  I know simply copying the .vhd files to the new RAID and pointing the VM to them does not work.  The only other things I've been able to ascertain are:

1)  I can re-import the exact same VM to the new location, but FIRST I have to delete the old VM from HYPV manager.  I'm not comfortable doing this.

2)  I can import the VM as a NEW VM.  I'm concerned about all of the issues that might crop up with having a new VM.  For instanc, I remember reading something about an issue with the virtual network card and MAC address.  Will I have to reconnect all of the client computers?  Will I have to re-set-up remote web access/remote client access? 


I guess I'm hoping there's away to accomplish option 1 without having to permanently delete the old VM.  I'm open to any suggestions!

Ticket.description:
So we have a two node 2012 R2 Cluster. We are using Starwinds for shared storage. We have 10 VM roles, 1 dhcp server role and 3 Scale out file server Roles.


Our goal is to provide maximum up time for the VM's and some important file shares.  The file share data is actually more important than the VM's. The shares are users, projects and operations.  Each share is 1.5 TB max with around 300GB used on each one.


Not sure why, but when we originally designed this, Starwinds highly recommended that we create the file shares using the scale out file server role vs using the standard file server role or creating a "VM File server" to share the files.  So right now each of the shares is on a SOFS Role and shared to the users from there. From everything I've read this is NOT the way file server user shares should be setup. See when to use a SOFS. The system currently works and fails over without issues but we're having issues to trying to backup the files. The VM's backup fine with no issues with just about any backup software. The problem is the file share data. Most backup software doesn't support MS clusters or doesn't work with SMB 3.0 or has some other little issue that makes it not work reliably or runs slower than I can deal with. Veeam file copy works but it's so slow. We're getting like 2MB/sec.  


Finally my question. What is the proper way to set this up to make backing up easy? Preferably with Veeam. We want to keep one or two copies onsite and one offsite. Spinning up the environment offsite would be great but is not mandatory, maybe something we can do in the future.


Because nearly all backup software is geared towards backing up VM's these days (not the files on the file share), my gut tells me to just create a VM and share the files from the VM. The problem with that is the VM's become huge (3x1.5 TB) and will take forever to migrate and restore. The current VM's are around 50GB and restore or migrate very quickly.


Any help would be greatly appreciated.

Ticket.description:
I'm working on doing a server migration and running into some weird issues that I was hoping I could get some advice on.  Here is all the information in regards to the setup, old and new, and what has happened thus far.

Old server: Windows server 2012 essentials: Domain controller, file and printer server.

New Server: Vmware 6.5 running a vm of windows server 2012 r2 standard.

I started off by moving files over. Once that transfer completed, I  began by adding the new server to the domain. It was added successfully. I then installed the roles on the new server and after a restart, followed the steps to promote the server to be an AD server. I then proceeded to transfer the 5 fsmo roles, and afterwards running netdom query fsmo showed all the roles assigned to the new server. In the past at this point I've been able to remove the server from the network, update dns, and proceed with the setup. However this is the point where I hit a wall. AD logins stopped responding once the old server was removed, and the new server was not indicating on the network card that it was linked to a domain network, even though the primary dns was pointed at itself. Everything appeared to be working properly from a settings perspective, but other pcs showed the echo %logonserver% as the old server, and attempting to RDP into the new server with domain credentials resulted in an error indicating it could not contact the domain controller. Reconnecting the old server resulted in things working properly again, so to me this seems to indicate the AD transfer didn't complete, even though all signs pointed to it completing. I had to transfer the fsmo roles back and then I attempted again later, still getting the same error. At this point I'm reformatting the new server install and starting over again, but wanted to get any advice on what issue I may be running into.

Ticket.description:
At my company, we have folder redirection enabled for all users so their desktops, documents, etc are all stored on our file server. Additionally, our users with laptops and Surfaces (all Windows 8.1 or 10) have offline files enabled so their redirected folders are available when they're off-network.

We're in the process of replacing our SAN and moving everything over to the new one. For reasons unknown to me, our old "file server" was not a Windows VM, but instead just a share running directly off the old SAN, meaning that just moving a VM or using DFS replication to copy all the data was not a possibility.

So over the weekend I used Robocopy to copy all the data off the old SAN share onto a new Windows 2012 R2 virtual machine. I verified everything copied over, verified all the permissions and ACLs were correct, etc. Then I switched the GPOs for folder redirection and our network share mappings to point to the new server.

As a precautionary measure, since the GPOs were pointed directly to the old SAN (\\san\shares\users\%username%; \\san\shares\departments\%something%; etc), we disabled the shares on the old SAN, so that clients that didn't update their paths correctly wouldn't be writing to a stale location.

This worked fine for our desktop computers - except for a few minor hiccups, our desktops are all connecting to the new SAN, redirection and shares are working good, etc.

Our portable devices though are not cooperating quite as well. We've had a number of them still trying to connect to the old SAN, not getting the updated redirection/share paths, and just staying in a perpetual "offline" mode. To counter this, we tried removing the DNS record for the old SAN and replacing it with a CNAME pointing to the new file server, so that portable devices trying to connect to the old SAN would redirect to the new one and hopefully sync their files, but the Offline Files is still seeming to remain in an offline state, even though pinging the old SAN's name returns the correct IP of the new file server.

So we are starting to use more and more Windows 10 machines than Windows 7 and starting to notice some policies that aren't carrying over. 

When a user logs into a Windows 7 machine, it adds folders to the start menu with shortcuts to specific websites. There are a few folders that have the same URL as other folders. This is intention as we want our users to look up the site by the product name even though some of the products all use the same URL on the back end. For example:


Product 1
URL 1
Product 2URL 1 

We've noticed in our Windows 10 (1709) machines that it only list duplicate URLs once. Even if the URL shortcuts have different names, it will only show one shortcut to the website instead of the many shortcuts of the same URL with different names. 

Am I missing something? Is this intention and if so, does anyone know a way around this?

Ticket.description: I have some users that are running some very resource intensive processes which often consume many GBs worth of RAM. Often times a user will run a job which ends up consuming close to 100% of the system's RAM (which in our case is around 100GB). The issue in our case, is the disparity between what the user sees reported in Task Manager vs what I (the admin) see reported in Resource Monitor. Task Monitor is reporting that the user's process is using 1.3GB of RAM while Resource Monitor reports the process has 3.7GB committed to memory and 100GB in working memory. Because the user is not able to see this memory issue in Task Manager, they assume the issue is caused by other users on the VM. Without having admin privileges, are there any good ways for a user to view more info on their RAM usage?

Ticket.description:
Hello all,

In the process of adding a new larger RAID to our server.  Set-up is a Dell PE T610 running Server 2008 R2 on the physical machine hosting a 2012 R2 Essentials VM through HyperV.  Currently has a PERC H200 card and 4TB RAID10 that I'm replacing with am H710 card and 8TB RAID10.  Due to changing controller cards (and purposely not attempting the unsupported foreign config import from the H200 to H710), and wanting to be able to completely revert back to the old setup if things go sideways, my only option is to copy the VM to an external USB drive, disconnect the old RAID, connect the new RAID, copy the VM back to the new RAID.

The big question is, HOW to do this exactly.  And what is the most reliable and least complicated method.  I've been reading everything I can find, but there is precious little info on re-importing a VM to the exact same physical host.  I know simply copying the .vhd files to the new RAID and pointing the VM to them does not work.  The only other things I've been able to ascertain are:

1)  I can re-import the exact same VM to the new location, but FIRST I have to delete the old VM from HYPV manager.  I'm not comfortable doing this.

2)  I can import the VM as a NEW VM.  I'm concerned about all of the issues that might crop up with having a new VM.  For instanc, I remember reading something about an issue with the virtual network card and MAC address.  Will I have to reconnect all of the client computers?  Will I have to re-set-up remote web access/remote client access? 


I guess I'm hoping there's away to accomplish option 1 without having to permanently delete the old VM.  I'm open to any suggestions!

Ticket.description:
So we have a two node 2012 R2 Cluster. We are using Starwinds for shared storage. We have 10 VM roles, 1 dhcp server role and 3 Scale out file server Roles.


Our goal is to provide maximum up time for the VM's and some important file shares.  The file share data is actually more important than the VM's. The shares are users, projects and operations.  Each share is 1.5 TB max with around 300GB used on each one.


Not sure why, but when we originally designed this, Starwinds highly recommended that we create the file shares using the scale out file server role vs using the standard file server role or creating a "VM File server" to share the files.  So right now each of the shares is on a SOFS Role and shared to the users from there. From everything I've read this is NOT the way file server user shares should be setup. See when to use a SOFS. The system currently works and fails over without issues but we're having issues to trying to backup the files. The VM's backup fine with no issues with just about any backup software. The problem is the file share data. Most backup software doesn't support MS clusters or doesn't work with SMB 3.0 or has some other little issue that makes it not work reliably or runs slower than I can deal with. Veeam file copy works but it's so slow. We're getting like 2MB/sec.  


Finally my question. What is the proper way to set this up to make backing up easy? Preferably with Veeam. We want to keep one or two copies onsite and one offsite. Spinning up the environment offsite would be great but is not mandatory, maybe something we can do in the future.


Because nearly all backup software is geared towards backing up VM's these days (not the files on the file share), my gut tells me to just create a VM and share the files from the VM. The problem with that is the VM's become huge (3x1.5 TB) and will take forever to migrate and restore. The current VM's are around 50GB and restore or migrate very quickly.


Any help would be greatly appreciated.

Ticket.description:
I'm working on doing a server migration and running into some weird issues that I was hoping I could get some advice on.  Here is all the information in regards to the setup, old and new, and what has happened thus far.

Old server: Windows server 2012 essentials: Domain controller, file and printer server.

New Server: Vmware 6.5 running a vm of windows server 2012 r2 standard.

I started off by moving files over. Once that transfer completed, I  began by adding the new server to the domain. It was added successfully. I then installed the roles on the new server and after a restart, followed the steps to promote the server to be an AD server. I then proceeded to transfer the 5 fsmo roles, and afterwards running netdom query fsmo showed all the roles assigned to the new server. In the past at this point I've been able to remove the server from the network, update dns, and proceed with the setup. However this is the point where I hit a wall. AD logins stopped responding once the old server was removed, and the new server was not indicating on the network card that it was linked to a domain network, even though the primary dns was pointed at itself. Everything appeared to be working properly from a settings perspective, but other pcs showed the echo %logonserver% as the old server, and attempting to RDP into the new server with domain credentials resulted in an error indicating it could not contact the domain controller. Reconnecting the old server resulted in things working properly again, so to me this seems to indicate the AD transfer didn't complete, even though all signs pointed to it completing. I had to transfer the fsmo roles back and then I attempted again later, still getting the same error. At this point I'm reformatting the new server install and starting over again, but wanted to get any advice on what issue I may be running into.

Ticket.description:
At my company, we have folder redirection enabled for all users so their desktops, documents, etc are all stored on our file server. Additionally, our users with laptops and Surfaces (all Windows 8.1 or 10) have offline files enabled so their redirected folders are available when they're off-network.

We're in the process of replacing our SAN and moving everything over to the new one. For reasons unknown to me, our old "file server" was not a Windows VM, but instead just a share running directly off the old SAN, meaning that just moving a VM or using DFS replication to copy all the data was not a possibility.

So over the weekend I used Robocopy to copy all the data off the old SAN share onto a new Windows 2012 R2 virtual machine. I verified everything copied over, verified all the permissions and ACLs were correct, etc. Then I switched the GPOs for folder redirection and our network share mappings to point to the new server.

As a precautionary measure, since the GPOs were pointed directly to the old SAN (\\san\shares\users\%username%; \\san\shares\departments\%something%; etc), we disabled the shares on the old SAN, so that clients that didn't update their paths correctly wouldn't be writing to a stale location.

This worked fine for our desktop computers - except for a few minor hiccups, our desktops are all connecting to the new SAN, redirection and shares are working good, etc.

Our portable devices though are not cooperating quite as well. We've had a number of them still trying to connect to the old SAN, not getting the updated redirection/share paths, and just staying in a perpetual "offline" mode. To counter this, we tried removing the DNS record for the old SAN and replacing it with a CNAME pointing to the new file server, so that portable devices trying to connect to the old SAN would redirect to the new one and hopefully sync their files, but the Offline Files is still seeming to remain in an offline state, even though pinging the old SAN's name returns the correct IP of the new file server.
